body:
We had a similar issue some time ago, fixed in https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/51073, but so that still relies on the `arr is not result` identity check. 

This seems to be caused by a peculiarity (or bug?) in numpy related to how the object dtype array comes back from `pickle`. Using your code example from above, the object dtype instance from the unpickled array is different from the "default" instance:

```
>>> t.dtype is np.dtype("object")
True
>>> tp.dtype is np.dtype("object")
False
```

And then I assume that `np.asarray(.., dtype="object")` uses such a check above, and therefore returns the original array in case of `t` but returns a new object in case of `tp`.

According to `np.asarray` docs, if order and dtype are the same as the original array, it does not copy and return the original array. 
It does sound like a bug in asarray, or at least it's not entirely documented. 
I'll open an issue in numpy to see what they think there. 
Assuming it is not a bug, in order to fix this particular issue, It's possible to use `np.shares_memory` to trigger copy (can be costly) or `np.may_share_memory` - which should be faster but return some false positives
What do you think?

issue.title: BUG: np.asarray return a copy with shared memory

repository.name: numpy
repository.description: The fundamental package for scientific computing with Python.

issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

According to `np.asarray(a)` [docs](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.asarray.html#numpy-asarray), it may return the original array or a copy.
In the case below, while `np.asarray(a, dtype='object') is not a`, - `np.shares_memory(np.asarray(a, dtype='object'), a)` given that a is copied.



### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
import pickle
t = np.array([None, None, 123], dtype='object')
tp = pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(t))
g = np.asarray(tp, dtype='object')

assert g is not tp
assert np.shares_memory(g, tp)  # Unexpected
g[0] = '1'
assert tp[0] == '1'  # Unexpected


# The issue seems to be originated here
assert not np.dtype('O') is pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(np.dtype('O'))) 
assert np.dtype('O') == pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(np.dtype('O')))
```


### Error message:

_No response_

### Runtime information:

I'm using pandas and have pickled dataframes, when using `df.astype(str)` the dataframe is changed in-place
see [issue](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/54654) in pandas

body: `np.may_share_memory(result, arr)` or `np.shares_memory(result, arr, max_work=np.MAY_SHARE_BOUNDS)` should be safe and fast for this use case. In the cases that `np.asarray()` does make a copy of the data, it will not be in overlapping bounds.

issue.title: BUG (string dtype): fix inplace mutation with copy=False in ensure_string_array

labels.name: Strings
labels.description: String extension data type and string data

repository.name: pandas
repository.description: Flexible and powerful data analysis / manipulation library for Python, providing labeled data structures similar to R data.frame objects, statistical functions, and much more

issue.body:
Further follow-up on https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/54654, https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/54687, https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/57212, because we still had the issue when `copy=False` was passed (which happens when casting to any of the string dtypes).

The added tests failed without the actual code change.

(smaller change extracted from https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/59685/)

xref https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/54792
